results.title: Walk the talk
results.creator_credit: Jan Chapman, Mandy Walker, Shirley Barrett and NBCUniversal
results.brief_description: Shirley Barrett displayed a penchant for black comedy with her successful debut feature “Love serenade”. “Walk the talk”, her second feature, is a darkly comic tale about several deluded individuals trying to govern unreachable dreams of stardom. Joey is a con man fresh out of prison after serving a stint for selling fake cellulite cream. His girlfriend is Bonita, confined to a wheelchair, and awaiting a one million dollar compensation payout. Joey’s latest scheme on his road to glory is to sell the minimal talents of Nikki, a bad-tempered singer and dancer. Joey convinces Bonita to bankroll his idea and he creates a plan that will make both him and Nikki rich and famous. The cultural milieu unique to Surfers Paradise in Queensland is milked for laughs - Nikki’s father mocks her for being a showbiz failure, where as he has made it as an entertainer of pensioners between their rounds of bingo. When Joey’s grand scheme to make Nikki a star goes awry, he makes the decision that no act is unworthy if it results in fame, or at the very least infamy, for the pair.

results.title: Hollywood or bust
results.creator_credit: Hal B. Wallis, Frank Tashlin and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Hollywood or bust marked the last collaboration between Jerry Lewis and Dean Martin and the second time the pair were directed by Frank Tashlin (who directed numerous Jerry Lewis comedies). When Steve Wiley (Dean Martin) rigs a car raffle in order to pay off the bookies that he is deeply indebted to, he also lands a partnership with Malcolm Smith (Jerry Lewis), the real winner of the prize. With a new car, Malcolm decides to head to Hollywood in order to meet the starlet he is besotted with, Anita Ekberg (playing herself); Steve decides to join him and hopefully win some dough in the Las Vegas casinos to pay the henchmen after him. The two head cross-country with Malcolm’s great dane in tow; they also lend a ride to Terry (Pat Crowley), a pretty singer for whom Wiley falls. This musical comedy and road movie contains much of the usual slapstick that was Lewis’ signature schtick; it also plays up to Martin’s image as the smooth and charming lady-killer. Reportedly the shoot was not a fun one with Lewis being a difficult and rambunctious presence on set.

results.title: I Was a male war bride
results.creator_credit: Sol Siegel, Howard Hawks and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Classic Howard Hawks’ comedy sees Cary Grant play Captain Henri Rochard, a French officer who falls for an American army official staioned in Europe. Following the chaos however, and bureaucratic red-tape that marked the cessations of hostilities in World War 2, the pair find it almost impossible to make their union legal. Circumstances force Rochard to pose an a ‘war bride’ in order to secure happiness, which of course leads to no end of strife and embarrassment for the eager groom.

results.title: Worse than Xmas
results.creator_credit: Joanne Aslanis, Mandy Walker and Julie Harris
results.brief_description: Waitress Angela (Kaarin Fairfax) rushes home to save a doomed relationship. When she fails, she agrees with her neighbour that Easter is the worst time of year, even worse than Christmas. The film follows the funny and inevitable diversions that Angela takes to make it through the breakup and start dating again.

results.title: The Well
results.creator_credit: Sandra Levy, Mandy Walker, Samantha Lang, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: Hester (Pamela Rabe) is a lonely woman who has spent all her life on her father’s farm in outback NSW. Katherine (Miranda Otto), is a young woman alone in the world until she comes to live with Hester as her housemaid. The two form a happy friendship, until one night it all falls apart when Katherine runs over and kills a man. The haunting cinematography and strong acting performances produce a powerful tale of rural isolation and trust betrayed. Cinematography by Mandy Walker.

results.title: Love serenade
results.creator_credit: Jan Chapman, Mandy Walker, Shirley Barrett, AFFC and Saddleback Productions
results.brief_description: Two bored sisters Dimity and Vicki-Ann live in a small country town. Their new neighbour, a brooding self-centered radio personality arrives on the scene and threatens to turn their world upside down. Dimity and Vicki-Ann find themselves in competition for his affections as each develops a severe crush on the aging Lothario with a predilection for ‘70’s music and young women. Awarded the Camera D’Or at the 1996 Cannes Film Festival and starring Miranda Otto and Rebecca Frith (as the love-torn sisters) alongside George Shevtsov and John Alansu. Cinematography by Mandy Walker.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jan Chapman, Mandy Walker, Shirley Barrett, AFFC and Saddleback Productions

results.title: Return home
results.creator_credit: Cristina Pozzan, Mandy Walker, Ray Argall and Musical Films
results.brief_description: Noel, divorced, middle-aged, takes a break from his high pressure job in a big corporation to visit his brother, who, with his wife, is struggling to hang onto a barely viable small business - a service station in Adelaide. Gary, the 19 year old apprentice is struggling to come to terms with the complexities of life as an emerging adult and befriends Noel. Before long, Noel rediscovers the pleasures of family and is revitalised. After his return to Melbourne, his brother Gary and wife Judy, reassess their own lives and begin to see their own potential. Noel eventually returns to Adelaide for good; his journey for happiness, security and a future filled with promise is finally over. Ray Argall’s direction gives form and substance to everyday lives. A sense of naturalism is apparent. Stars Dennis Coard, Frankie J. Holden, Ben Mendelsohn and Micki Camilleri. Cinematography by Mandy Walker. Also available on DVD [319217]

results.title: Gunfight at the O.K. Corral
results.creator_credit: Hal B. Wallis, John Sturges and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Considered to be one of the best western films ever made, director John Sturges explores the relationship between two of the west’s most celebrated legends - Wyatt Earp (Burt Lancaster) and Doc Holliday (Kirk Douglas). Earp is a U.S. Marshal in Dodge City and Holliday a dentist - turned gambler - who knows how to handle a gun. When Earp saves Holliday from mob violence, the foes become friends and join forces to rid the west of the lawless Clanton gang. It all leads up to the legendary Gunfight at the O.K. Corral. Screenplay by Leon Uris. Featuring a small appearance by a very young Dennis Hopper.

results.title: Salt, saliva, sperm and sweat (AFC)
results.creator_credit: Philip Brophy, Mandy Walker, Rod Bishop and 1 for Dumb Films
results.brief_description: A relentless journey into the banalities of everyday life - a film about the body - eating, excreting, sex, violence, masturbation and terror. The voyeuristic camera lewdly follows Phillip Dean, an extraordinarily ordinary office worker, to the office, to the toilet, to the same French restaurant every night and finally to bed. The film depicts the “body” as an all consuming machine which has its basis in the consumption and ejaculation of moisture in the forms of salt, saliva, sweat and sperm. Starring Phillip Dean, Jean Kitson, Lyndal Barry, Robert Chuter, Daniel Scharf, Cheyanne Armitage, Nicholas Kanigan and Martina Murray. Best Australian Film - 1988 Melbourne Film Festival.

results.title: Koorie culture, Koorie control (A)
results.creator_credit: Lucy MacLaren, Mandy Walker, Russell Porter, Museum Victoria, Film Victoria and Mozo Films
results.brief_description: Through a series of interviews with members of Victorian Aboriginal communities, this video gives a broad understanding of the unwritten and undocumented history of Victoria. Issues such as the protection of sites of significance, the return of Aboriginal skeletal remains to their home and the significance of passing on Koorie culture to the young are all raised in this program, which stresses the importance of the Aborigines managing their own land. Accompanied by Teacher’s notes.
